lessonOverview.title: Unit 1 - Lesson 1
structures: A: Have you got a boat?
B: Yes, I have. / No, I haven’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six beach objects (rubber ring, water gun, boat, beach ball, life jacket, bucket) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show flashcards of beach objects. Say each word. Students repeat and then match them to SB images.
stretchStrategies: ❝Yes/No Beach Sort❞ – Place flashcards (or drawings) of beach items on the board. Say sentences like “I’ve got a boat” or “I haven’t got a beach ball.” Students come up and move the flashcard to the Yes or No side. Then, they take turns saying their own sentences for a partner to sort.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about possessions using "I've got a.../I haven't got a..." and ask and answer simple questions using "Have you got a...?" with responses like "Yes, I have." / "No, I haven't."
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Use classroom items or cards. Ask: “Have you got a rubber ring?” Students respond using “Yes, I have” or “No, I haven’t.”
stretchStrategies: ❝Yes/No Beach Sort❞ – Place flashcards (or drawings) of beach items on the board. Say sentences like “I’ve got a boat” or “I haven’t got a beach ball.” Students come up and move the flashcard to the Yes or No side. Then, they take turns saying their own sentences for a partner to sort.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say statements using the target structure “I've got a ___.” / “I haven't got a ___.” and ask and answer questions using the target structure "Have you got a ___?" / "Yes, I have." / "No, I haven't." to talk about possessions.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write the question and answer on the board: “Have you got a ___?” / “Yes, I have.” Students practise with a partner using objects from SB.

items: Certain common holiday activities are less likely to overlap with those of Western kids (eating seafood at the beach, going on tours in large groups)
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
